tips.tip: Arikayce retail cost exceeds $15,000/month ($180,000+ annually), but most patients don't pay full price - insurance covers with copays, and Insmed offers patient assistance programs to reduce out-of-pocket costs
tips.notes: Multiple patients report successfully getting Arikayce covered by insurance. One patient specifically mentions filling out Insmed patient assistance forms and getting approved to reduce monthly costs. Arikayce developed at cost of ~$1 billion per Dr. Griffith

tips.tip: New Brinsupri (brensocatib) retail cost is $88,000/year for either 10mg or 25mg dose, but Medicare $2,000 annual cap for all prescriptions (starting 2025) will limit out-of-pocket costs significantly
tips.notes: Retail price announced during Insmed conference call. Medicare Part D $2,000 annual out-of-pocket cap started in 2025 makes expensive drugs more affordable. Doctors beginning to submit qualification paperwork for patients

tips.tip: Medicare Part D 2025 changes: $2,000 annual out-of-pocket cap for covered drugs, can spread payments over year instead of paying all upfront - dramatically reduces cost burden for expensive NTM medications
tips.notes: Part of Affordable Care Act. One patient example: OFEV retail cost $153,762.60 annually but capped at $2,500 under Medicare. Critical for patients on multiple expensive drugs like Arikayce, Dupixent, etc.

tips.tip: Use Medicare.gov Plan Compare tool during open enrollment (ends Dec 7) to enter all current AND potential future medications with dosages to find Plan D that covers most drugs at best price
tips.notes: Part D formularies vary by state. Ask doctor what drugs you MIGHT need in coming year based on disease progression. Some plans cover Arikayce, Nuzyra (omadacycline), some don't. Brensocatib not yet in most formularies but Medicare expected to cover once FDA approved. Tool also checks pharmacy coverage

tips.tip: Contact independent Medicare agent or your state SHIP (State Health Insurance Assistance Program) office for unbiased help comparing Part D plans for NTM-specific medications
tips.notes: SHIP called SHIBA in Washington state. Independent agents can enter all medications into their systems and find best plan. More efficient than doing yourself since they know formularies across multiple carriers

tips.tip: GoodRx and AARP Prescription Discount cards can dramatically reduce costs for non-covered medications like 7% hypertonic saline - prices vary by pharmacy and region, so compare
tips.notes: 7% saline typically NOT covered by Medicare Part D. Actual patient costs: GoodRx at Walgreens $25.84/90 days (CA), AARP card at CVS $21/90 days (NY) vs $63/90 days (IL), RiteAid with GoodRx $18/60 vials. Pharmacies can check multiple discount cards to get best price. AARP card free with membership

tips.tip: For out-of-network specialist care, file formal appeals with insurance stating no in-network NTM/bronchiectasis specialist available - include doctor letters documenting medical necessity and complexity of disease
tips.notes: Multiple detailed physician letters increase success rate. One patient got Blue Shield PPO continuity of care approval when provider contract at risk. Include: disease complexity, specialist expertise needed, lack of in-network alternatives, treatment plan details

tips.tip: Kaiser HMO members report Kaiser will NOT refer out to NTM specialists even when they lack expertise - patients forced to self-pay for National Jewish or UCSF care if wanting specialized treatment
tips.notes: Northern CA and Southern CA Kaiser patients both report this issue. Hawaii patient notes Kaiser considers their 'substandard' island care sufficient despite inability to perform full BE workup or complete pneumonia titer testing (only 16 of 23 strains). Consider PPO instead of HMO if possible

tips.tip: When insurance initially denies expensive medication, switch to PPO plan during next open enrollment if currently on EPO/HMO, or file multiple appeals with updated clinical documentation
tips.notes: One patient had to wait almost a year until open enrollment to upgrade from Anthem EPO to Anthem PPO. For denials, persistence matters - multiple appeals with different clinical justifications can succeed where initial request failed

tips.tip: Airway clearance vest insurance coverage highly variable - some insurers charge $300-1,000/month rental until 'paid off,' making $1,200 outright purchase often cheaper than rental over time
tips.notes: Example: Insurance wanted $300/month then $1,000/month after deductible. Total rental cost far exceeds $1,200 outright purchase price. SmartVest offers patient assistance and helps with insurance navigation. Hill Rom also has patient assistance programs. Check if rental actually required or if insurance will cover purchase

tips.tip: Always call insurance company directly to verify whether DME (durable medical equipment) requires rental vs can be purchased - DME companies make extra money on rentals and may misrepresent insurance requirements
tips.notes: Patient found company claimed 'rental required' but insurance actually would cover purchase. Request list of all in-network DME companies from insurance, then call each to find one willing to work with you on purchase vs rental and who knows what supplies are covered

tips.tip: Vest manufacturers (SmartVest, Hill Rom) offer patient assistance programs that can significantly reduce costs - contact them directly to fill out assistance forms, separate from insurance coverage
tips.notes: Multiple patients successfully used manufacturer assistance programs. SmartVest specifically mentioned as helpful with both customer service and financial assistance. Worth exploring even if insurance partially covers

tips.tip: Difficult-to-get medications like omadacycline (Nuzyra) for M. abscessus vary dramatically by Medicare Part D plan - Aetna Medicare Advantage PPO covers it, while many other plans deny despite appeals
tips.notes: Patient with Medicare Part D failed multiple appeals for omadacycline, only oral option left for abscessus. Switching to Aetna Medicare Advantage PPO in 2025 solved problem. Delaware analysis: HealthSpring and Wellcare cover some abscessus/pseudomonas drugs but NOT Nuzyra. Check Medicare.gov tool with specific drug before open enrollment

tips.tip: Medicare Part D formularies vary by state and change annually - same carrier may have different drug coverage in different states, and drugs can go on/off formulary mid-year
tips.notes: Wellcare, Cigna, HealthSpring, AARP Medicare Rx, UHC, Humana, Blue Shield all have different state-specific formularies. Cheaper drugs sometimes drop off formulary while expensive ones added - 'makes absolutely NO sense' per patient comment. Must check annually

tips.tip: For newly FDA-approved drugs like Brinsupri, insurance may not have added to formulary yet - pulmonologist can request coverage through qualification paperwork and medical necessity documentation during launch phase
tips.notes: Brinsupri FDA approved Aug 2025, not yet on most formularies. Doctors submitting qualification paperwork now. Patient reports signing forms at pulmonologist office who handles records submission. Medicare expected to cover once in formulary. Launch phase typically takes months before broad formulary adoption

tips.tip: Life insurance with bronchiectasis diagnosis extremely difficult to obtain - many brokers unfamiliar with condition, and single positive MAC culture (even if second culture negative) may disqualify applicants
tips.notes: 46-year-old otherwise healthy patient with BE and one positive MAC culture (second negative, so technically no MAC diagnosis) still unable to find life insurance. Brokers never heard of bronchiectasis. Likely need specialized high-risk life insurance broker

tips.tip: Plan G Medicare supplement is most comprehensive supplement plan available (different from Plan D drug coverage) - no medical questions required when first eligible for Medicare, but must answer health questions if switching later
tips.notes: Plan G is supplement, Plan D is drug plan - two separate things often confused. Important to get best supplement plan (Plan G) when first Medicare-eligible since no underwriting required. Changing later requires medical underwriting which may be denied with NTM diagnosis

tips.tip: Discount cards (GoodRx, AARP) cannot be combined with insurance - use whichever gives better price. Pharmacies can check multiple cards in their system to find lowest cost for non-covered medications
tips.notes: CVS stores often have multiple discount cards on file (GoodRx, AARP, CVS own discount) and will automatically apply best one. Walgreens accepts GoodRx but some stores report 'new policy due to fraud' - try different Walgreens location if one refuses. Safeway GoodRx only works once at cheaper price, then increases

tips.tip: Some medications covered under Medicare Part B (medical) instead of Part D (drugs) if used with nebulizer - how prescription written may determine which part covers it
tips.notes: One patient successfully gets saline covered under Part B for several years 'may be because of how prescription written.' Albuterol covered under Part B but equipment to nebulize it not covered - system doesn't always make sense

tips.tip: When comparing Plan D options, consider monthly premium + projected drug costs + deductible together - cheapest premium doesn't mean lowest total annual cost if drug coverage worse
tips.notes: Example: Wellcare $17.40/month vs Cigna $1.80/month, but with $2,000 cap, total annual difference only ~$186. More important that plan covers all your expensive drugs. Run total cost projection on Medicare.gov including all current + potential drugs

key_insights: Medicare Part D 2025 $2,000 annual out-of-pocket cap is game-changer for NTM patients - makes drugs costing $88,000-180,000 annually actually affordable, but must verify drugs are on plan's formulary

Insurance navigation requires active self-advocacy - calling insurance directly, comparing multiple discount cards, filing appeals with detailed medical documentation, and switching plans during open enrollment often necessary to access needed care

Discount cards (GoodRx, AARP) critical cost-savings tool for non-covered medications like 7% saline - can reduce costs 60-80%, but prices vary wildly by pharmacy/region and pharmacies can check multiple cards to find best price

DME companies profit from rentals over purchases - independently verify with insurance whether rental required, as companies misrepresent requirements; outright purchase often cheaper long-term than rental payments

Out-of-network specialist access depends on insurance type - Kaiser HMO won't refer out even without expertise (forcing self-pay), while PPO plans more likely to approve appeals with proper documentation of lack of in-network alternatives

Medicare Part D formularies vary dramatically by state and carrier, change annually, and don't always make logical sense (cheaper drugs drop while expensive added) - must research during EVERY open enrollment with current+projected drug list

Manufacturer patient assistance programs separate from insurance - Insmed (Arikayce), SmartVest, Hill Rom all offer financial help programs that can significantly reduce costs even when insurance covering some

common_questions.question: How much does Arikayce actually cost patients out-of-pocket?
common_questions.answer: Retail cost exceeds $180,000/year, but actual patient costs vary widely. With insurance coverage, most pay copays. Insmed offers patient assistance programs - patients report filling out forms and getting approved to reduce costs. Starting 2025, Medicare Part D $2,000 annual cap limits out-of-pocket for all covered prescriptions, making Arikayce much more affordable if on formulary.

common_questions.question: How do I find Medicare Part D plan that covers my NTM medications?
common_questions.answer: Use Medicare.gov Plan Compare tool during open enrollment (ends Dec 7). Enter ALL current medications PLUS drugs you might need in coming year (ask doctor). Include dosages and quantities. Tool shows which plans cover what at which pharmacies. Consider contacting independent Medicare agent or state SHIP office for unbiased help - they can enter meds into their systems and find best match. Plan D formularies vary by state.

common_questions.question: What's the difference between Medicare Plan D and Plan G?
common_questions.answer: Plan G is Medicare supplement (covers medical costs like copays, coinsurance) - most comprehensive supplement available. Plan D is prescription drug coverage (separate). Both needed for complete coverage. Important: Get Plan G when first Medicare-eligible (no health questions), as switching later requires medical underwriting which may deny with NTM diagnosis.

common_questions.question: How can I reduce cost of 7% hypertonic saline?
common_questions.answer: 7% saline typically NOT covered by Medicare Part D. Use discount cards: GoodRx or AARP Prescription Discount (free with AARP membership). Actual costs: $18-28 for 60-90 days depending on pharmacy and card. Ask pharmacy to check multiple discount cards to find best price. CVS, Walgreens, RiteAid all accept cards but prices vary by region. Cannot combine discount card with insurance - use whichever gives better price.

common_questions.question: Will insurance cover out-of-network NTM specialist?
common_questions.answer: Depends on insurance type. PPO plans more likely to approve with proper appeals showing no in-network specialist available + detailed doctor letters documenting medical necessity. Kaiser HMO specifically will NOT refer out even when lacking expertise - forces self-pay for National Jewish or other specialists. One patient upgraded from EPO to PPO during open enrollment to get out-of-network coverage. File formal appeals with multiple physician letters for best chance.

common_questions.question: Should I rent or buy an airway clearance vest?
common_questions.answer: Call insurance directly to verify whether rental required - DME companies profit from rentals and may misrepresent requirements. Example: Company wanted $300-1,000/month rental (totaling far more than purchase), but insurance would actually cover purchase. Outright vest purchase ~$1,200. SmartVest and Hill Rom offer patient assistance programs. Get list of in-network DME companies from insurance and compare.

common_questions.question: What if insurance denies my expensive NTM medication?
common_questions.answer: Multiple strategies: (1) File appeals with updated clinical documentation - multiple appeals with different justifications can succeed, (2) Have doctor submit medical necessity letters explaining why drug critical, (3) Contact drug manufacturer for patient assistance program (separate from insurance), (4) Switch to different Plan D or PPO plan during next open enrollment that covers the drug, (5) For Medicare: starting 2025, $2,000 annual cap makes even denied-then-approved drugs affordable.

common_questions.question: How do GoodRx and AARP discount cards work?
common_questions.answer: Both provide discounts for non-covered medications - cannot be combined with insurance. Use whichever gives better price for specific drug at specific pharmacy. AARP card free with membership ($12-16/year). Many pharmacies (CVS especially) have multiple cards on file and will automatically check which gives best price. Prices vary wildly by region and pharmacy chain. Some Walgreens refusing GoodRx due to 'fraud policy' - try different location.
